text: Tell me about Bangladesh men's cricket
responses: Bangladesh men’s national team is administered by the Bangladesh Cricket Board (BCB). Nickname: The Tigers. BCB founded in 1972 (as BCCB), renamed in 2007; HQ: Sher‑e‑Bangla National Cricket Stadium, Mirpur, Dhaka; site: tigercricket.com.bd.
The Tigers are Bangladesh’s men’s team, run by the BCB (est. 1972, renamed 2007), headquartered at Sher‑e‑Bangla, Mirpur. Website: tigercricket.com.bd.
BCB origin: 1972 as BCCB; renamed to Bangladesh Cricket Board in 2007. HQ: Sher‑e‑Bangla National Cricket Stadium, Mirpur, Dhaka. Website: tigercricket.com.bd.
The BCB runs Bangladesh cricket; HQ is at Sher‑e‑Bangla, Mirpur. Founded 1972, current name since 2007. Official site: tigercricket.com.bd.

text: Where does Bangladesh stand in ICC rankings?
responses: As of Nov 2025: Test 9th, ODI 10th, T20I 9th. ODI 10th sits outside the top‑8 automatic qualification for the 2027 World Cup (hosts + top 8).
Rankings (Nov 2025): Tests 9, ODIs 10, T20Is 9. ODI position is just outside the automatic 2027 CWC spots.

text: Who was the first captain of Bangladesh?
List of all Bangladesh cricket captains
responses:
Here is the list of key Bangladesh Captains:

**Test Captains:**
1. Naimur Rahman (Inaugural, 2000)
2. Khaled Mashud
3. Khaled Mahmud
4. Habibul Bashar (First Test win)
5. Mohammad Ashraful
6. Shakib Al Hasan
7. Mushfiqur Rahim (Most Tests as captain)
8. Mahmudullah
9. Mominul Haque
10. Najmul Hossain Shanto

**ODI Captains (Notable):**
1. Gazi Ashraf (First ODI captain, 1986)
2. Minhajul Abedin Nannu
3. Akram Khan (1997 ICC Trophy)
4. Aminul Islam Bulbul (1999 WC)
5. Habibul Bashar
6. Mashrafe Mortaza (Most successful, 50 wins)
7. Tamim Iqbal
8. Shakib Al Hasan

**T20I Captains:**
1. Shahriar Nafees (First T20I)
2. Mashrafe Mortaza
3. Shakib Al Hasan
4. Mahmudullah
5. Najmul Hossain Shanto
6. Litton Das (Current)

The history of Bangladesh captains:
* **First ODI Captain:** Gazi Ashraf (1986)
* **First Test Captain:** Naimur Rahman Durjoy (2000)
* **First T20I Captain:** Shahriar Nafees (2006)
* **Most Successful (ODI):** Mashrafe Mortaza
* **Most Successful (Test):** Mushfiqur Rahim/Shakib Al Hasan
* **Other Legends:** Akram Khan, Aminul Islam, Habibul Bashar, Tamim Iqbal.
Split captaincy (2025): Test – Najmul Hossain Shanto (to WTC 2027), ODI – Mehidy Hasan Miraz, T20I – Litton Das.
Captains in 2025: Shanto (Tests), Miraz (ODIs), Litton (T20Is).

Coaches (2025): Head – Phil Simmons (to 2027); Batting – Mohammad Salahuddin; Pace – Shaun Tait; Spin – Mushtaq Ahmed. Mohammad Ashraful served as interim batting coach for the Nov 2025 Ireland series.
Bangladesh coaching: Phil Simmons (head), Salahuddin (batting), Tait (pace), Mushtaq (spin). Ashraful was interim batting coach vs Ireland (Nov 2025).
CT 2025 (ODI) squad: Shanto (C), Soumya, Tanzid Hasan Tamim, Parvez Emon, Hridoy, Mushfiqur, Mahmudullah, Jaker Ali, Miraz (VC), Rishad, Nasum, Taskin, Mustafizur, Tanzim Sakib, Nahid Rana.

Bangladesh CT 2025: Najmul Hossain Shanto (C), Mehidy Hasan Miraz (VC), Mushfiqur Rahim, Mahmudullah, Tawhid Hridoy, Soumya Sarkar, Tanzid Hasan, Parvez Emon, Jaker Ali, Rishad, Nasum, Taskin, Mustafizur, Tanzim Sakib, Nahid Rana.

text: Bangladesh T20 squad for Asia Cup 2025
responses: Asia Cup 2025 (T20I): Litton Das (C, wk), Tanzid Hasan, Parvez Emon, Saif Hassan, Hridoy, Jaker Ali (wk), Shamim Hossain, Nurul Hasan Sohan (wk), Mahedi Hasan, Rishad, Nasum, Mustafizur, Tanzim Sakib, Taskin, Shoriful, Shaif Uddin. Standby: Soumya, Miraz, Tanvir Islam, Hasan Mahmud.

Led by Litton Das, Bangladesh’s Asia Cup 2025 (T20I) squad featured pace: Mustafizur, Taskin, Shoriful, Tanzim; spin: Rishad, Nasum, Mahedi; plus Hridoy, Emon, Tanzid, Shamim, Sohan, Jaker Ali, Saif Hassan, Shaif Uddin.

text: Who is in the Bangladesh Test team vs Ireland?
responses: Test squad vs Ireland (Nov 2025): Shanto (C), Shadman, Mahmudul Hasan Joy, Mominul, Mushfiqur, Litton, Jaker Ali, Miraz, Taijul, Syed Khaled, Hasan Mahmud, Nahid Rana, Ebadot, Hasan Murad.
Ireland Tests (Nov 2025) squad includes: Shanto, Shadman, Joy, Mominul, Mushfiqur, Litton, Jaker Ali, Miraz, Taijul, Khaled, Hasan Mahmud, Nahid Rana, Ebadot, Hasan Murad.
Ireland tour (Bangladesh) 2025: Tests – Nov 11–15 (Sylhet), Nov 19–23 (Mirpur). T20Is – Nov 27 & 29 (Chattogram), Dec 2 (Mirpur).
Fixtures: 1st Test Nov 11–15 Sylhet; 2nd Test Nov 19–23 Mirpur; T20Is Nov 27 & 29 in Chattogram, Dec 2 in Mirpur.

text: How did Bangladesh do in Tests 2024 2025?
responses: Tests 2024–2025: 2–0 win in Pakistan (Aug 2024); 0–2 losses vs India (Sep 2024) and South Africa (Oct 2024); 1–1 draws vs West Indies (Nov 2024) and Zimbabwe (2025); 0–1 loss vs Sri Lanka (Jun 2025).
Standout: historic 2–0 away Test series win in Pakistan (Aug 2024); mixed home results through 2025.

text: How is Bangladesh doing in ODIs?
responses: ODIs 2024–2025: 2–1 win vs Sri Lanka (Mar 2024); losses 0–3 vs WI (Dec 2024), 1–2 vs AFG (Nov 2024), winless CT 2025; 1–2 vs SL (Jul 2025); 0–3 vs AFG (Oct 2025); 1–1 vs WI (Oct 2025).
ODI form dipped in away/neutral venues in 2025, impacting rankings and 2027 CWC qualification push.
T20Is 2025: 3–0 win vs Afghanistan (UAE), 2–0 win vs Netherlands; mixed results vs Sri Lanka, Pakistan, West Indies; win vs Hong Kong and UAE.
T20I summary: strong vs AFG and NED in 2025; series loss 1–2 to WI (Oct 2025).

text: How did Bangladesh get Test status?
responses: Milestones: BCCB formed 1972; ICC Associate 1977; ICC Trophy win 1997; first World Cup 1999; ICC Full Member and Test status on 26 Jun 2000.
Path to Tests: 1977 ICC Associate → 1997 ICC Trophy win → 1999 World Cup debut → Full Membership in 2000.
First ODI: vs Pakistan, 31 Mar 1986 (Asia Cup). First Test: vs India, Nov 10–13, 2000 (Dhaka). First T20I: vs Zimbabwe, 28 Nov 2006 (Khulna) – won by 43 runs.
Debuts: ODI 1986 vs Pakistan; Test 2000 vs India; T20I 2006 vs Zimbabwe (won).

First Test win: vs Zimbabwe, Jan 2005 (Chittagong). First Test series win: vs Zimbabwe (2005). First overseas Test series win: 2–0 vs West Indies (2009). First ODI win vs Australia: Cardiff 2005 (Ashraful 100). First 10‑wicket wins: ODI vs Ireland (2023), Test vs Pakistan (2024), T20I vs USA (2024).
Notables: ODI win vs India (2004), vs Australia (2005), multi‑nation trophy: 2019 Ireland tri‑series.

In 1999, Bangladesh competed in their first World Cup (there was no Champions Trophy that year). Captain: Aminul Islam Bulbul. Coach: Gordon Greenidge. Squad includes: Akram Khan, Minhajul Abedin Nannu, Khaled Mahmud Sujon, Khaled Mashud Pilot, Mohammad Rafique, Naimur Rahman Durjoy, Enamul Haque Moni, Hasibul Hossain, Shahriar Hossain, and Mehrab Hossain. Historic Moment: Beat Pakistan by 62 runs.

The major event of 1999 was the World Cup in England. Captain: Aminul Islam Bulbul. Coach: Gordon Greenidge. Key Players: Akram Khan, Minhajul Abedin, Khaled Mahmud. Result: Wins against Scotland and Pakistan.

text: Who was captain in 2000 Champions Trophy?
responses: Bangladesh's ICC Champions Trophy debut (then called ICC KnockOut) was in Oct 2000 vs England. Captain: Naimur Rahman Durjoy. Squad: Javed Omar, Shahriar Hossain, Habibul Bashar, Akram Khan, Aminul Islam, Al Sahariar, Khaled Mashud, Mohammad Rafique. Result: Lost by 8 wickets.
In the 2000 ICC KnockOut (Champions Trophy), Bangladesh was led by Naimur Rahman Durjoy. They played one match against England in Nairobi and lost.

text: How many World Cups Bangladesh played?
responses: ODI World Cup: first appearance 1999; 7 editions (1999–2023). Best: Quarter‑finals in 2015; Super Eights in 2007 with a famous win over India; finished 8th in 2019.

text: Best T20 World Cup result Bangladesh
responses: T20 World Cup: first in 2007; appeared in every edition through 2024. Best: Super 8s in 2007 and 2024. Bangladesh hosted the 2014 event.
Bangladesh reached the Super 8s twice (2007, 2024); hosts in 2014.

text: How many times runner up Asia Cup Bangladesh
responses: Asia Cup: 16 appearances; runners‑up 3 times – 2012 (ODI), 2016 (T20I), 2018 (ODI).
Best Asia Cup finish: runners‑up in 2012, 2016, 2018.
Highest team totals: Test 638 (vs SL, Galle 2013); ODI 349/6 (vs IRE, Sylhet 2023); T20I 215/5 (vs SL, Colombo 2018).
Record highs: Test 638; ODI 349/6; T20I 215/5.
Lowest totals: Test 43 all out (vs WI, 2018); ODI 58 all out (vs WI 2011; vs IND 2014); T20I 70 all out (vs NZ, 2016).
Team lows: Test 43; ODI 58; T20I 70.

Largest wins: Test by runs – 546 vs Afghanistan (Mirpur, 2023); Test by wickets – 10 vs Pakistan (Rawalpindi, 2024); ODI by runs – 163 vs Sri Lanka (Dhaka, 2018); ODI by wickets – 10 vs Ireland (Sylhet, 2023); T20I by runs – 84 vs PNG (2021); T20I by wickets – 10 vs USA (2024).
Record margins: 546‑run Test win (AFG 2023) and first 10‑wicket wins in ODI (IRE 2023) and Test (PAK 2024).
Most Test runs: Mushfiqur Rahim 6,328; Tamim Iqbal 5,134; Shakib Al Hasan 4,609; Mominul Haque 4,412 (approx).
Leaders (Tests): Mushfiqur, Tamim, Shakib at the top (as of late 2025).
Most ODI runs: Tamim Iqbal 8,357; Mushfiqur Rahim 7,795; Shakib Al Hasan 7,570; Mahmudullah 5,689.
ODI run leaders: Tamim, Mushfiqur, Shakib lead the charts.
Most T20I runs: Litton Das ~2,590; Shakib Al Hasan 2,551; Mahmudullah 2,444; Tamim Iqbal ~1,700+.
T20I runs: Litton recently moved top; Shakib and Mahmudullah follow.
Most Test wickets: Shakib Al Hasan 246; Taijul Islam ~218; Mehidy Hasan Miraz 205; Mohammad Rafique 100.
Test wicket leaders: Shakib leads, followed by Taijul and Mehidy.
Most ODI wickets: Shakib Al Hasan 317; Mashrafe Mortaza 269; Abdur Razzak 207; Mustafizur Rahman 174; Taskin Ahmed 117.
ODI wickets: Shakib heads the list; Mashrafe second.
Most T20I wickets: Shakib Al Hasan 149; Mustafizur Rahman ~132–155; Taskin Ahmed ~103–106 (ranges reflect 2025 updates).
T20I wickets: Shakib leads; Mustafizur and Taskin next.

text: Tell me about Shakib Al Hasan
responses: Shakib Al Hasan (b. 1987) – left‑hand bat, left‑arm orthodox. Bangladesh’s greatest all‑rounder; leading wicket‑taker in Tests (246), ODIs (317), T20Is (149). Top‑3 run‑scorer across formats. Retired from T20Is in 2024; Tests in 2024; set full retirement after 2025 Champions Trophy.
Career bests: Test 217, ODI 134*, T20I 84; best bowling 7/36 (Test), 5/29 (ODI), 5/20 (T20I).

Tamim Iqbal (b. 1989) – left‑hand opener. Bangladesh’s leading ODI run‑scorer (8,357) and most ODI hundreds (14). Highest T20I score for Bangladesh (103*). Retired from internationals; led Fortune Barishal to BPL titles in 2024 and 2025.
Career highs: Test 206, ODI 158, T20I 103*.

Mushfiqur Rahim (b. 1987) – wicket‑keeper batter. Bangladesh’s Test run leader (6,328) and holder of the highest Test score (219*). Most Test (127) and ODI (299) dismissals for Bangladesh. Retired from ODIs after CT 2025; set to reach 100 Tests in Nov 2025.
Key feats: first Bangladeshi with three Test double hundreds; ODI runs 7,795.
Mashrafe Mortaza (b. 1983) – right‑arm fast, ex‑captain. Bangladesh’s most successful ODI captain (50 wins). Joint‑best ODI bowling for Bangladesh: 6/26 vs Kenya (2006). ODI wickets: 269.
Career: ODI 220 matches, 270 wickets; nickname: Narail Express.

text: Tell me about Aminul Islam Bulbul
responses: Aminul Islam Bulbul (b. 1968) – pioneer, former captain. Scored Bangladesh’s first Test century: 145 vs India in their inaugural Test (2000). Later worked in ICC cricket development.
Bulbul’s Test best: 145; ODI best: 70.
Akram Khan (b. 1968) – former captain; led Bangladesh to the 1997 ICC Trophy, enabling 1999 World Cup qualification. Played in the inaugural Test (2000); later BCB chief selector.
Akram ODI runs: 976; Tests: 259.

text: Tell me about Najmul Hossain Shanto
responses: Najmul Hossain Shanto – left‑hand batter, current Test captain. Only Bangladeshi with centuries in both innings of a Test on two separate occasions; top run‑scorer for Bangladesh at T20WC 2022 (180).
Career (2025): Tests ~2,189 runs (HS 163); ODIs ~1,705 (HS 122*); T20Is ~987.
Litton Das – wicket‑keeper batter, current T20I captain. Bangladesh’s top T20I run‑scorer (~2,590). Holds Bangladesh’s highest ODI score (176 vs Zimbabwe, 2020).

text: Tell me about Mehidy Hasan Miraz
responses: Mehidy Hasan Miraz – all‑rounder, current ODI captain. Fastest Bangladeshi to 2,000 Test runs and 200 wickets (53 matches). Third‑most Test wickets (205).
Career bests: Test 6/60; ODI 6/43; T20I 5/22.
Taskin Ahmed – right‑arm fast; leader of the pace attack. ODI debut 5/28 vs India (2014). Among Bangladesh’s top T20I wicket‑takers (~103–106) and 5th in ODI wickets (117).
Career bests: Test 6/64; ODI 5/28; T20I 4/16.
Mustafizur Rahman – left‑arm fast; known for his variations. ODI debut 5/50 vs India (2015). Among Bangladesh’s top ODI wicket‑takers (135) and T20I wicket‑takers (~132–155).
Career bests: Test 7/58 (match 12/117), ODI 4/25; batting HS Test 104, ODI 112*.

Mahmudullah Riyad (The Silent Killer) – All-rounder. Historic achievements: First Bangladeshi to score a World Cup century (2015). Hero of the 2017 Champions Trophy win vs NZ (102*). Known for finishing tough games.
Career Highlights: Scored back-to-back centuries in 2015 WC. Retired from T20Is in 2024 and Tests in 2021. Remains a key middle-order batter for ODIs (Champions Trophy 2025 squad).

Habibul Bashar Sumon (Mr. Fifty) – Former captain. He led Bangladesh to their first-ever Test match victory (vs Zimbabwe, 2005) and first ODI series win over India (2004). Known for being the most consistent run-scorer in the early Test era.
Stats: 3,026 ODI runs and 24 half-centuries (hence the nickname 'Mr. Fifty'). Currently serves as a BCB selector.

Mohammad Ashraful – The prodigy. Holds the world record as the youngest player to score a Test century (17 years, 61 days vs Sri Lanka, 2001). Famous for his 100 vs Australia in Cardiff (2005) which led to the historic upset.
Role: Former captain. Served as interim batting coach for the Ireland series in Nov 2025.

text: First Bangladesh bowler to 100 Test wickets
responses: Mohammad Rafique – Legendary left-arm spinner. He was the first Bangladeshi to take 100 Test wickets and 100 ODI wickets. A key member of the 1997 ICC Trophy winning team and the 1999 World Cup team.
Style: Accurate spinner and handy lower-order hitter. Man of the Match in Bangladesh's first-ever Test win (2005).
Tawhid Hridoy – Right-handed middle-order batter. Emerged as a vital run-scorer in 2023-2025. Key member of the T20 World Cup 2024 and Champions Trophy 2025 squads.
Known for high strike rates and composure under pressure. Regarded as the future anchor of Bangladesh's batting lineup.
Taijul Islam – Left-arm orthodox spinner. A Test specialist. Holds the record for the best ODI bowling figures by a Bangladeshi on debut (hat-trick vs Zimbabwe, 2014).
Test Record: Second/Third highest wicket-taker for Bangladesh in Tests (200+ wickets). Known for long spells and accuracy.
